article:
In chemical processing, a 'packed bed' is a hollow tube, pipe, or other vessel
that is filled with a packing material. The packing can be randomly filled with
small objects like Raschig rings or else it can be a specifically designed
structured packing. Packed beds may also contain catalyst particles or
adsorbents such as zeolite pellets, granular activated carbon, etc.

The purpose of a packed bed is typically to improve contact between two phases
in a chemical or similar process. Packed beds can be used in a chemical reactor,
a distillation process, or a scrubber, but packed beds have also been used to
store heat in chemical plants. In this case, hot gases are allowed to escape
through a vessel that is packed with a refractory material until the packing is
hot. Air or other cool gas is then fed back to the plant through the hot bed,
thereby pre-heating the air or gas feed.
